review.title: Solving the Wastewater Treatment Plant Problem with SMT
review.abstract: In this paper we introduce the Wastewater Treatment Plant Problem, a real-world scheduling problem, and compare the performance of several tools on it. We show that, for a naive modeling, state-of-the-art SMT solvers outperform other tools ranging from mathematical programming to constraint programming. We use both real and randomly generated benchmarks.

sections.heading: 3.1 Problem statement
sections.text: An instance of the WWTPP problem results from (1) a single resource with a given capacity, (2) a series of tasks with a specific duration, release time and resource capacity, (3) a chain-like precedent relationship between the tasks, (4) for such a task chain, a buffer (or retention basin) with a given capacity and output rate (we assume the input rate is flexible), and (5) an overall time period (greater than all release times), the question is to find a schedule in which (1) each task is either planned at the time of its release (and does not exceed the deadline) or is redirected to the appropriate buffer with a volume corresponding to its resource capacity requirement multiplied by its duration, (2) the capacity of each buffer is never exceeded, (3) each buffer is preventively emptied with the appropriate capacity, the buffer capacity is emptied at a specific time and the required buffer capacity is not exceeded at a specific time.
